overview_of_class:
Cultural and linguistic anthropology has long been concerned with questions of social justice and

inequality. This ethnography-based course focuses on actors who seek individual or collective rights and

recognition through legal and paralegal means, and the social processes and changes that affect them

through a broad, cross-cultural approach to both "law" and "human rights." Case studies concern

refugees, indigenous peoples, political opponents, children and women, religious minorities, and other

marginalized populations. The concept and pursuit of human rights through legal advocacy,

humanitarianism, and individual narrative is considered through international units such as the

European Court, the United Nations, and the World Bank, as well as at local and state levels. Course

requirements include weekly response papers, seminar participation, discussion facilitation, and a final

paper.
name: Topics in Anthropology
